title: Zero must belong

lemmas.name: LinearAlgebraGame.neg_one_smul_v
lemmas.altTitle: {K V} (fk : Field K) (acg : AddCommGroup V) (vs : LinearAlgebraGame.VectorSpace K V) (v : V) : -1 • v = -v

lemmas.name: LinearAlgebraGame.smul_zero_v
lemmas.altTitle: {K V} (fk : Field K) (acg : AddCommGroup V) (vs : LinearAlgebraGame.VectorSpace K V) (a : K) : a • 0 = 0

lemmas.name: LinearAlgebraGame.subspace_contains_zero
lemmas.altTitle:
{K V} (fk : Field K) (acg : AddCommGroup V) (vs : LinearAlgebraGame.VectorSpace K V) {W}
  (hW : LinearAlgebraGame.isSubspace W) : 0 ∈ W

lemmas.name: LinearAlgebraGame.subspace_neg
lemmas.altTitle:
{K V} (fk : Field K) (acg : AddCommGroup V) (vs : LinearAlgebraGame.VectorSpace K V) {W}
  (hW : LinearAlgebraGame.isSubspace W) (x : V) (a✝ : x ∈ W) : -x ∈ W

lemmas.name: LinearAlgebraGame.zero_smul_v
lemmas.altTitle: {K V} (fk : Field K) (acg : AddCommGroup V) (vs : LinearAlgebraGame.VectorSpace K V) (w : V) : 0 • w = 0

lemmas.name: MulAction.mul_smul
lemmas.altTitle: {α} {β} [Monoid α] [MulAction α β] (x y : α) (b : β) : (x * y) • b = x • y • b

lemmas.name: Nat.add_succ
lemmas.altTitle: (n m : ℕ) : n + Nat.succ m = Nat.succ (n + m)

lemmas.name: add_right_cancel
lemmas.altTitle: {G} [Add G] [IsRightCancelAdd G] {a b c} (a✝ : a + b = c + b) : a = c

lemmas.name: add_smul
lemmas.altTitle: {R} {M} [Semiring R] [AddCommMonoid M] [Module R M] (r s : R) (x : M) : (r + s) • x = r • x + s • x

lemmas.name: le_iff_exists_add
lemmas.altTitle: {α} [CanonicallyOrderedAddCommMonoid α] {a b} : a ≤ b ↔ ∃ c, b = a + c

lemmas.name: one_smul
lemmas.altTitle: (M : Type u_1) {α} [Monoid M] [MulAction M α] (b : α) : 1 • b = b

lemmas.name: smul_add
lemmas.altTitle: {M} {A} [AddZeroClass A] [DistribSMul M A] (a : M) (b₁ b₂ : A) : a • (b₁ + b₂) = a • b₁ + a • b₂

lemmas.name: symm
lemmas.altTitle: {α} {r} [IsSymm α r] {a b} (a✝ : r a b) : r b a

introduction:
Now that we understand what a vector space is, and have proven a simple theorem about
them, let's define what a subspace is. Intuitively, a subspace is a subset of a vector space that
can be considered as a vector space itself. We define this as a subset `W : Set V` that is nonempty,
is closed under addition, and is closed under scalar multiplication.

### The `obtain` tactic
A new tactic will help us solve problems with subspaces. While not necessary, and this tactic can
even be completely replaced by the `cases'` tactic, it will simplify your proofs greatly. The `obtain`
tactic essentially acts as repeating `cases'`. In this level, it has two main uses. First, if `hw : isSubspace W`
is a hypothesis, then `obtain ⟨h1, h2, h3⟩ := hW` will split the definition into the three parts,
labeled h1, h2, and h3. The other important use for `obtain` is if you have a hypothesis `hW : W.Nonempty`,
then `obtain ⟨w, hw⟩ := hW` will give you a `w : V`, and a hypothesis `hw : w ∈ W`. Also, the "⟨"
character is written with "\langle", and the "⟩" character is written with "\rangle".

### Subspace contains zero
One of the basic properties of a subspace is that it must be nonempty. In fact, every subspace must
contain the zero vector. This is because for any vector in a subspace, you can multiply it by the zero
scalar while still remaining in the subspace, which wil result in the zero vector. In this level, we
formally prove this result.
descrText: This is a proof that any subspace contains the zero vector.
descrFormat: theorem subspace_contains_zero (fk : Field K) (acg : AddCommGroup V) (vs : VectorSpace K V) {W : Set V} (hW : isSubspace (K := K) (V := V) W) : (0 : V) ∈ W  := by
